Fast and no lag.The WiFiIt connected to my Wifi with no issues, preformed a speed test and my Download speed was 40MBPS and my upload was 37MBPS (I have Comcast Bussiness class 50M/50M).The GPSFound my location within minutes, I also notice that you do not have to have the WiFi on to use the GPS a plus in my book, and it include Google Maps and Navigation. 2 item The Galaxy Tab 3 did not have.The PerformanceLaunch Play store and it was so fast that it update all my apps before I could find in MYAPPS, the Netflix and the HBO Go, and the MAX Go Application. (one note MAX Go is not supported on this device), But Netflix launched within second and I was streaming the Avengers without a hiccup . HBO go loaded slowly the first time but after that it take a few second and the clarity of the screen was very impressive. Application pop, they are so fast that I often click on the next screen because I am so used to the lag that I anticipate the next step, well I need to break that habit with this tablet. Web Browsing, YouTube (and Flash can be Supported go to adobe achieve and download Adobe Flash for ICS 4.xx), there was no wait on loading. And then it happened, while watching YouTube I click on the menu bar and the video was now in a window, I could drag it to any part of the screen and the video was still playing without losing sync or even being choppy. I could now browse other item even other website while still watching the video. I am impressed.... I cannot comment on the performance with games, my daughter (okay I went back and bought another one for myself, hey 2 for the price of just 1 Nexus 7, wouldn't you?)  Really just play movies, streams video, edits pictures and chats with her friends. She did say that the Front facing camera is kind of washed out at times but with Skype it was perfect, and video chatting was flawless.OverallThis is a fantastic product, a product that I would have never thought of looking at because I thought it was and off brand, was I ever so wrong. This is a Quad Core 1.2 GHZ and it has its own on board GPU with 1 GB ram. Internal Memory is 16GB (the Galaxy Tab 3 7 was only 8GB and it was $50 more), it has a 1280 by 800 (Galaxy was 1024 by 600) the Camera were about the same spec, the Asus does not have the IR Blaster but my daughter or me for that fact are not going to use this as a remote to my entertainment system, I have the Harmony One and I am not changing that for nothing. I cannot say enough about how impressed I am with this Tablet. I keep throwing things at it and it keep chewing them up and spitting them out. I have yet to bring it to its knees.ConclusionLet's be honest everyone has an opinion. And opinion and perception can differ greatly when talking about likes and dislikes. But hear me and the others that have made almost exactly the same comments about The Asus MeMo Pad HD 7 (ME173x), it's price to performance is stellar, it's display is top line, it feature are impressive. What else can I say just go and look at it, take it for a test run in the store, bring a microSD, loaded with the hardest to play movies and put it in the tablet and play it, then tell me if all of us who rave about this Tablet are wrong....

Reviews.Title: AMAZING VALUE - do yourself a favor and buy this tablet.
Reviews.Author: Sally "Sally"
Reviews.Content: I put about six days into researching tablets and ended up buying a 64gig Blackberry Playbook. I had it one day before I returned it. Its wi-fi connection was super slow and there were very few useful or common apps in their store.I had already eyed the MeMoPad HD7, but was nervous about it because I was not familiar with the brand and honestly, I felt nervous because of the low price. After reviewing the specs thoroughly, and re-discovering that it had everything I wanted, and no other tablet from any other manufacturer had this combination of features at this price, I purchased one.I am not going to list the specs because you can see them in the product listing, but I will say this - I have zero buyer's remorse; after I took shipment back in September 'til now, it's been a true life love affair.I love how I can have all my emails come in through the one client, and it gives me access to everything I need to do with my social media outreach for business.The long battery life is stellar and the product is super fast.In the reviews I saw before I purchased, the only negative I saw people mention was the placement of the power and volume buttons. I admit it's a tiny bit unusual and a wee bit awkward, but I am willing to overlook that to get this fully loaded product for an incredible price.The unit has worked perfectly since the day I got it and I look forward to using it for a very long time. Because of my extensive research prior to purchase, and my daily use since buying it, I have been in a position to recommend it to anyone and everyone in the market for a tablet.Buy it - you will never regret it. 10/10 Asus - you have a new fan.

Reviews.Title: Very good device for an excellent price
Reviews.Author: Vyshtia
Reviews.Content: Owning an iPad and an iPad Mini, this device was a little hard to get used to at first.  The quality is not up to par when compared to an iPad, but the price is so much more affordable and it can do so much, that the quality really is good enough.  It really makes me wonder why the iPad costs so much when something like this can do just about everything it can do at such a more affordable price.  The size of this unit is slightly smaller than an iPad Mini.  It's very light, fits well in the hand, very good quality, does not feel or look cheap.  I would definitely recommend this tablet to anyone on a budget.  It can do everything I would want a small tablet to do.  It's fast, the screen/colors are beautiful, it handles games well.  It charges well and holds its charge.  It's quite durable too.  I think this is an excellent tablet and can definitely recommend without hesitation.

Reviews.Title: Terrific tablet for the price!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I had been searching for a replacement tablet for my iPad 3 for a few months. I knew I couldn't spend that amount again and to be honest, I was rather "underwhelmed" with the iPad. Maybe I'm just not "techie" enough. LOL I purchased a 10 inch Acer tablet from Woot! 2 months ago. It died within 2 weeks so I was nervous to say the last about trying again. But I had been watching this Asus HD 7 tablet for a while now, watching and reading reviews from C-net and other places and it seemed a brilliant buy for the price.Web pages are a little harder to read on a 7 inch tablet than a 10 inch but the text is clear and crisp and the display is just beautiful. I love all the pre=loaded aps and if you don't like them they are easy to remove. The battery life is awesome, even when using the camera and video recorder which I have a lot. I know a lot of people say that this camera is just "ok" but I really think it takes an awesome picture, even in lower lights. With no flash it doesn't do well in really low light though. In daylight, outside, pics are just beautiful. There are lots of tweaks that come with the tablet as well, to change photo settings etc. The video recorder is also great. My family is involved in Dog Obedience competition and we wanted something to record training sessions as well as at shows. This will work perfectly.Sound is great, picture on screen is great, plays you tube videos. Comes with a Kindle Books app which is great because I can download ebooks from my local library for free in Kindle format.All in all I'd give this 4.5 out of 5 stars. Why not 5? Well the case is plastic instead of the metal like my iPad and the glass is not gorilla glass and it does smudge; however it makes for a lighter tablet than the iPad. but I bought a nice PU leather cover for it tht came with a stylus (it was like 12 bucks here on Amazon) and the nice thing is when you close the cover the tablet hibernates; open the cover and it wakes up. No button pushing.

Reviews.Title: Loved it for two and one half weeks
Reviews.Author: JDandy
Reviews.Content: This tablet did everything well for two an one half weeks. I loved it. Then it simply died. The replacement lasted almost three weeks, then died. They will not even light up when attached to the charger. I have trusted Asus products for many years--used their PC parts and have a magnificent Asus monitor.  I am so disappointed in this tablet. Now, I have to research a replacement that will not break the bank!

Reviews.Title: Stopped working after 4 months
Reviews.Author: W. Design
Reviews.Content: I wanted to wait and see how this little machine performed. I read many of the reviews. Out of the box I was impressed. The advantage right out of the box was the cost vs. the quad core configuration. But being a tech head, I thought I would install a program that allowed me to monitor the heat level. I was concerned by the cheaper plastic casing and toy like fee of the tablet.Months went by not a problem. Hey I even recommended it to some friends but now I have to eat crow and it seems like this post may turn into a "Find Out How Good ASUS is on returns".The device started to overheat a few times and I got a few warnings then NOTHING. Now it won't turn on and I have tried a few different chargers. I will update everyone once I deal with ASUS since this is less than 6 months old...

Reviews.Title: Excellent value
Reviews.Author: Andrew H. Wakefield
Reviews.Content: Update after using this tablet for a month:I continue to be very pleased with it. At the new price of $129, it is a fantastic value. As I expected, battery life has stabilized. I get better overnight results if I turn off Wifi (even though I have the power-saving mode that is supposed to turn it off when sleeping). Others have complained about button and USB port placement; for me, these are not issues. I rather like the fact that I can hold the tablet in one hand without worrying about accidentally pressing a button. As for USB port on the top, if you don't like it, just turn the unit upside down; the screen will adjust automatically.One minor concern has surfaced. Occasionally after carrying the unit in my pocket (suit jacket or slacks), I have noticed what appears to be a little moisture in the screen. It appears as a dime-sized spot that gradually diminishes and then disappears. This does not seem to affect the screen from functioning, but does make me a bit concerned. If it continues, I will check with Asus to see if there is a simple fix.Original review:I bought this tablet to replace an aging Nook Color that I had set up as a full Android 2.3 tablet. After researching the options, the choice for me came down to the new Nexus 7 32 GB ($269), the Samsung Galaxy 3 Tab 7" 8 GB ($199), or this Asus MeMOPad HD 7 16 GB ($149). Everything I read suggested that the Nexus is the best tablet in terms of performance and screen ... and I love the Samsung Galaxy phone that I have ... but when I compared these three tablets in the store and via on-line reviews, I couldn't see that either the Nexus or the Samsung was going to be significantly better for my needs--certainly not enough to justify the extra cost.The fact that the new Nexus 7 lacks a Micro-SD port is a major consideration for me; even the 32 GB model would be a step backwards in total storage from my current Nook, and the less expensive 16 GB would be completely inadequate. In addition, the new Nexus 7 is quite a bit bulkier (longer) than the MeMOPad, which would be inconvenient for me, since I usually carry my tablet in my inside suit jacket pocket. (The MeMOPad fits very nicely.)The Samsung is a nice tablet, but after looking at a number of on-line reviews, including side-by-side reviews between the Samsung and the MeMOPad, I concluded that these two tablets are very similar in performance and screen--a conclusion borne out by my own side-by-side comparisons--so I opted to save the money and go with the Asus.After using the Asus MeMOPad for several days, I am quite pleased with my decision. Its performance is a huge step up from my old Nook, plus it has all the bells and whistles that I had wished for -- GPS, Bluetooth, and front and rear cameras. Movies play well (I use the MX Movie Player app rather than the built-in app so that I can play .AVI files), and streaming from Amazon Instant Videos is very smooth (unlike my old Nook). (Note that I added Adobe Flash, following instructions widely available on-line; I use the default browser to view flash-based videos.)Thus far, every app that I have installed has worked flawlessly. The one exception is Titanium Backup, which requires root access. I may investigate rooting the tablet down the road--I have already seen that there are various instructions on-line--but for now I don't see a compelling need. Some reviews suggested this is not the best tablet for the most demanding games, but it certainly handles the few games I play (mostly Temple Run and Angry Birds).I am still getting a sense of the battery life. I would say that so far it is acceptable, especially in terms of active use, but it has seemed to discharge a little faster than I would have expected when in sleep mode. My recollection is that it usually takes a while for a tablet to "settle down" as far as the battery cycle, and I have just barely begun to explore the various power-saving options that are available.To me the build quality seems very good. I have not noticed any squeaky or loose plastic. The texture of the case is pleasant to hold, and as noted above, the size is perfect for slipping into an inside pocket in a suit jacket. One important note is that the unit is essentially exactly the same size as the original Nexus 7; therefore, widely (and inexpensively) available accessories for the Nexus 7 may work well with this unit. For example, I bought a bluetooth mini-keyboard designed to function as a snap-on cover for the original Nexus 7; it works perfectly with the MeMOPad (both in terms of connecting and in terms of snapping on). One word of caution: full covers for the original Nexus 7 will lack a cut-out for the rear camera, and the micro-usb port for charging and transfer is on the top rather than on the bottom. Neither of these issues affect the mini-keyboard, since it only attaches over the screen.Bottom line is that this unit appears to me to be the best bang-for-the-buck available for a 7" tablet.

Reviews.Title: You cannot go wrong with this 7'' Android tablet.
Reviews.Author: Phalen
Reviews.Content: Wireless: As soon as I got the ASUS MeMO Pad HD 7 connected to wireless it updated to Android 4.2.2.  Fantastic.  Quick.  No connection drops.  Stays connected throughout my entire home (basement + 2 floors) with the router on the top floor in a corner bedroom.Display: 1280 x 800 display is very nice. Images do not need to be stretched or distorted into some crazy resolution. This results in images scaling properly. If you scan a pic of a 8.5x11'' book, for example, containing both images and text, and pull up the resulting image on the HD 7, it will be smaller (of course), but will still be clear and readable.  You can then two-finger zoom.  Still clear. The importance of a native resolution of 1280 x 800 cannot be overstated.  Viewing angle is good.  The previous version of this table (non-"HD 7" version) had a horrible issue with off-angle viewing.  This one has no problems with any reasonable angle.  Screen is as bright as you need it to be.  I have not tried it in direct sunlight but I will check it out and report back.Performance: Snappy.  Tried multiple apps and all performed well.  The Universe" on Netflix looked great.  Occasional, very slight, stutter.  But a 720p show on a tablet? At this price point? I think you can live with a stutter or 2.  Note that I'm not trying to run Photoshop (or whatever the Android equivalent might be) on this thing.  Because I'm not silly.If you're looking for an Android tablet to use with the Kindle reader app, you're going to be happy. If you've scanned your old novels, mags, RPGs, etc., and you're looking for something in which to peep them, you're going to be happy.  Just remember it's only 7''.  Don't make that joke...don't be that guy...Also, there's a microSD slot.  You need one. The cloud is great but there's nothing like moving 32 gigs of tunes and pics from the PC to to the microSD and then moving the card to the tablet.I love this thing.

Reviews.Title: Great product and great value without big compromises
Reviews.Author: Dan Sutton
Reviews.Content: PROS:-Sharp and colorful screen-Very light weight-Powered with mini-USB not proprietary connector-Good performance--used popular apps like Minecraft, Netfix, Google Maps, and others; watched videos--no lag-Updates to Android 4.2.1 after initial setup-GPS is quick and accurate; stayed locked on when using Google Tracker app outdoors-Rear facing camera w/ good quality--many 7" tablets don't have a rear cameraCONS:-Blacks are slightly washed out when brightness is at 75% or higher-Feels delicate; good build quality but not ruggedSUMMARY: The pros and price definitely outweigh the couple cons and make them easy to overlook; recommended product!

Reviews.Title: Amazing Tablet For the Price
Reviews.Author: Trevor L "God is on the side of the army with...

} } } Length:: 1:11 MinsThe 7" tablet size turns out to be the perfect size for a lot of uses such as reading, surfing the web and reading email. That happens to be about the same size as a paperback book but much thinner. It's a handy size for carrying around. We have the 2012 Nexus 7 and iPad Mini in the house and they have similar specs so I'll compare those.First off the iPad Mini screen is 1/2" wider than the MemOPad HD or Nexus 7. That extra screen space is nice but the Android tablets are easier to hold in the palm of your hand. The MeMOpad is slightly thicker than the Nexus 7 but it actually makes it a little easier to pick up. Camera quality on the MemoPad HD is nice and seems on par with the other tablets but I don't use those cameras often. Even under fluorescent lights the results were nice. Even though the MemoPad has half the RAM as the Nexus 7, the performance seems about the same. The build quality on both of the ASUS tablets is similar though the Nexus seems a little nicer and solid. The MemoPad back feels like plastic. Of course the iPad feels really nice but at more than double the price it should.I think most people would get as much use from the MemoPad HD as the Nexus and save themselves about $80. One difference most people will notice is that the MemoPad is not a "Nexus" device so they will have to wait longer to get updated versions of Android over the air. The Nexus also has a higher resolution screen but honestly I don't see a big difference when using the device. The Nexus 2013 comes with HDMI support via a non-included adapter cable but both should support MiraCast (see video) with a compatible TV or by adding a MiraCast receiver to their TV or monitor and I think more people will be streaming content to their home theater over the next year instead of using inconvenient cables. The MemoPad has the ability to expand memory and transfer files though a microSD card slot and I think most will find that feature more valuable and it makes this tablet more "futureproof" since storage space won't be an issue.=================1=Bad, 10=Good=================Browsing Web 9Reading Book 8Watching Netflix 8Reading Email 7Creating Documents 5Connectivity 7 ( no HDMI)Battery Life 7LCD Quality 7Material Quality 7Responsiveness 7Speakers 5=================ASUS MeMOPad HD (Android 4.2.1)$1507-inch 1280x800 IPS4 Core, 1.2Ghz MediaTek CPU1GB Ram16GB Storage302gWireless:802.11b/g/n, BT, GPSConnectivity: microUSB, 3.5mm audio, microSDCameras: 5MP Rear, 1.2MP Front197mm x 121mm x 11mmASUS/Google Nexus 7 FHD Tablet (2013)(Android)$2307.02-inch 1920x1200 IPS4 Core, 1.5 Ghz Snapdragon S4 CPU2GB Ram16GB Storage290gWireless: 802.11a/b/g/n, BT 4.0, NFC, GPSConnectivity: microUSB, HDMI (with extra adapter cableCameras: 5MP Rear, 1.2MP Front200mm x 114mm x 9mmApple iPad Mini (2012) (iOS 6)$3407.9-inch 1024x768 IPS2 Core, 1 Ghz ARM Cortex-A9 CPU512 MB Ram16GB Storage308gWireless: 802.11a/b/g/n Wi-Fi, BT 4.0, GPSConnectivity: lightening, 3.5mm audioCameras: 5MP Rear, 1.2MP Front200mm x 135mm x 7mm

Reviews.Title: Exceptional tablet & Great price
Reviews.Author: Lori
Reviews.Content: I pre-ordered this tablet after much research. I wanted to stay within a strict budget of less than $200.00. Being a satisfied owner of an Asus Netbook for the past couple of years, I was happy to see Asus was coming out with a new HD version of their MeMo pad. After comparing several similarly priced tablets, I went with Asus because it has features some others didn't such as SD card expansion slot and bluetooth. I also liked that it came in a variety of colors.After three months of using this tablet, I am very happy with it's performance, graphics, and features. There has also been at least one system update and I am hoping rumors of an Android Jellybean update to 4.3 are true.The only disappointment when I first got my tablet was that it did not come with Swype writing capability pre-installed. But I quickly remedied that with a download of Swype for Android from the PlayStore.I read a lot of library e-books so this tablet is great for this purpose due to its light weight and ability to run the must popular e-reading software such as Kindle reader - which I use frequently.I also find that I use this tablet for nearly all of my web browsing and YouTube watching instead of my netbook.I would recommend this tablet to anyone who needs a great tablet for an outstanding price. Matter of fact, I paid $149 back in August, but today on Amazon. com I see it's down to $119!

Reviews.Title: I'm using it more than expected
Reviews.Author: Shala Kerrigan
Reviews.Content: I got this tablet because it was inexpensive, had a decent enough camera and would work for the apps that I use to promote my webpage. Then my computer died and it wound up getting a lot more use than expected for a couple of weeks.Everything about this tablet is better than I expected, the build, the display, the wi-fi speed, and how quickly apps load. The camera in it certainly won't replace a good digital camera but for using it with social networks, it does focus nicely and is easy to use. The microSD slot is a really good thing for being able to store more photos or transfer them to a computer with a card reader super quickly. The display is very clear and easy to see at a lot of angles except in bright sunlight. Bluetooth connectivity is good- I've been able to listen to music in my room on a mini speaker while this is in the living room- through 2 walls and another small room.I'm not a gamer, but have a few free game apps loaded to it and they all work well with no lagging. So even though I bought it primarily for social networking, it's also been just wonderful for keeping my family members occupied while waiting for me to finish errands.The battery life is good and it will run nearly all day on a charge for normal use. Playing games does use up the charge quicker.Because of the price, the one thing I dislike is a very minor issue. The shiny, smooth  screen takes and shows fingerprints worse than any device I've every used. I wind up wiping it down several times a day.I like the bright, pretty green color, and will probably pick up a second one in a different color for my husband.

Reviews.Title: 4.5 stars is my true assessment
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I opened this today and I am writing the review after some hours of enjoying it.First, the packaging was beautifully crafted, simple, secure, and protective.  The contents were basic too--and I like that. I had it set up and running in less than 10 minutes.  And if my home wifi was more cooperative, that timeframe might have only been 3-5 minutes.The processor is very quick. Tons of memory and micro SD supports an additional 32GB if you want.I spent the day downloading my favorite apps with no trouble and very little wear on the battery (I use the battery optimizer).The touch screen is very receptive and easy to use.  Yes, it attracts fingerprints.  That doesn't bother me.The sound is a decent quality for a tablet of this size. It is not an audiophile's dream, but let's remember we are talking about a 7" tablet here.The video and camera are clear and are HD when HD is available.  I have seen some reviews complaining that the picture was pixelated and grainy--just remember that on youtube, there are a lot of videos that are not loaded initially in HD, so you can't do anything about that.  The ones that are in HD, are crisp and clear on this tablet.There are a ton of ways to customize this tablet to your liking in the settings menu.ONLY CON I can come up with for myself--I haven't figured out how to watch amazon PRIME instant streaming videos.  Android doesn't support flash player after 4.0 (ICS), even though you can find it on the adobe flash player archive website and download it yourself.  It is still hit or miss as far as usability for me.  I will figure it out though.I am a basic user.  Like to check/send email, surf the web a bit, check my bank accounts, play a few simple games, read some online magazines.  I don't take a lot of pics or shoot video, but I might just start :-)  This is a perfect tablet for someone like me.  I had a generic tablet I paid 1/2 the price of this one--and I got exactly 1/2 the satisfaction and functionality from it.  This is a very reasonably priced piece of social technology.  I think user friendly enough for any age group (I am wishing my mum had one when she was housebound with illness).  And if you are worrying about "keeping up with the Jones' " and all their toys, you will not be ashamed to whip this out at the coffee shop or at the PTA meeting.I am sure I will get the hang of all the additional benefits of a high quality tablet like this very soon.Hope this review helps.  If anything strange comes up, I will update.  If not, then know I am content discovering all the different ways to enjoy this tablet.I bid you peace.

Reviews.Title: An Ipad Mini Killer for half the price
Reviews.Author: Timothy Logan
Reviews.Content: This is a winner of a 7" tablet. Lightweight, slim and yet powerful to run full HD video and HD games. There isn't another tablet on the market place that boost of a quad-core for this price. Touch is fast and smooth. Basic Asus apps are functional, thanks to two android stores, you have your choice of free and paid apps. With a built in 16gb drive and the ability to add an additional 32gb via the microSD slot, you will have plenty of room for your pictures, movies, music, apps and documents.So far, I have run the tablet for over 6 hours continuously, but I suspect I could run much longer if I turned off the GPS and WiFi. Overall, I'm impressed with this tablet and more impressed with the 149.99 price tag. The base ipad mini is still going to cost you over 300.00. After purchasing my cover and screen protector, I'm still under 200.00. That's just about at the price of a Galaxy 7. And the screen is gorgeous, Ipad mini list 1024x786 while the memo HD list 1280x800. It looks better than the much touted Ipad Mini Retina display.

Reviews.Title: ASUS MeMOPAD HD 7 - Meets Expectations
Reviews.Author: L. Hannenberg
Reviews.Content: I've had the device for a few days now and have had an opportunity to get used to it.  One of the reasons I wanted an Android device is because I like to listen to Pandora using headphones.  I like the option of being able to equalize the stream with one of many good equalizer apps.  This is something that is not possible on an ipad.  With equalization the sound quality is very good through headphones.I've had to restart the device a few times for various reasons.  Once while trying to use Google Hangouts I received a message stating no camera detected.  This was corrected with a restart.  On one occasion after the tablet was idle overnight Pandora froze while opening and required a restart to function properly.  It's been working fine since.The tablet meets my expectations which were relatively low given the price.  The screen is sharp, battery life good, and the device is comfortable to hold for long periods.  There is not a good selection of 3rd party covers/cases at this time.  I would like a neoprene case because the plastic is a bit slippery.I originally considered the Nexus 7, but after reading reports of product defects, along with the fact it doesn't have card expansion I decided to purchase the ASUS MemO.  I feel that device is well worth the money and would recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Returned to Asus three times
Reviews.Author: Keisha Simmons
Reviews.Content: Just received a new tablet yet again. (I purchased a blue tablet origionally and the last two times, the tablet comes back in black.) This tablet is less than six months from the time I purchased it. Yesterday I got the tablet out of the box by ASUS, and it won't charge. That is the exact reason I keep returning the product to ASUS is because the charger won't fit in the mechanism and won't hold a charge. So for the fourth time, I will be returning this tablet back to ASUS. NOW A WISE PURCHASE!

Reviews.Title: The best tablet at this price point.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I bought this tablet for my son with moderate expectations. After all you can't excpect too much from $130 tablet right?  WRONG!!!This tablet surprised me on every level of performance. Let me just mention that I have over 20 years experience as s professional IT and this would be my bread and butter.When I did my research I narrowed down 3 models: Galaxy, Nexus and MemoPadApple was not even an option in my research because of price/functionality ratio and the limitations imposed by Apple's proprietary approach. I like my computers and mobile devices to be open architecture rather than closed proprietary. But that's me.Being a computer builder for many years, I am well familiar with ASUS as I use their mother boards in most computers I built. They make some of the best motherboard in the market.Back to my research, the galaxy, although was an excellent candidate, was above the price I wanted to spend. So we are down to Nexus and MemoPad. Being produced by the same manufacturer (ASUS) I knew they both has the same quality. So now we are really down to feature comparison and of course price.These are the factors that helped me make final decision:1. The MemoPad has both front and back cameras. The Nexus has front camera only2. The MemoPad has SD card slot which allow you to expand the storage by 32GB. The nexus does not support external storage.3. Both devices support 1280 x 800 and showed excellent image quality when played a starwars movie converted from blu-ray4. Both devices come with quad processor5. Most of the rest of the features are identical or similar6. The MemoPad cost $126 while the nexus was $189You do the math ;-)

Reviews.Title: Stopped working after 4 weeks
Reviews.Author: Tabitha K
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my 7 year old as a santa gift. He took very good care of it and mostly used it to watch videos and play his little games. He was very careful with it, kept it in the protective case, charged it every night. Then one day in January it just wouldn't turn on. Couldn't charge it or anything. I contacted Amazon, and they replaced it. We were happy again for about 2 weeks and now the replacement has the same problem. Won't turn on, won't charge. Thank goodness amazon has such great customer service they are giving me a full refund. Hopefully we can get something better that will actually work.My 7 year old is disappointed in you, Santa.

Reviews.Title: Died on 2nd day
Reviews.Author: cheeweng
Reviews.Content: Looks like my gamble didn't paid off.. Only receive it yesterday, boot up, update firmware and install a few basic apps and stop using, left it on my home desk over night.. . I don't carry it to work... The very next day, when I pick it up after my dinner, it was shut down... I thought some apps I installed burn out the battery and I just plug in the charger but it won't charge... Nothing works... Looks like it's dead after less than 3 hours of usage... I'm not from states... Now have to find out how to rma it... Disappointed... I like asus product, I have nexus7, asus tf300tl transformer and thought of buying an entry level for my son use... Bad move...

Reviews.Title: Junk
Reviews.Author: bbeny "SomeGuy"
Reviews.Content: So, I purchased 2 of these after reading all the great reviews.  After about 5 months, the first tablet just died.  Would not turn on and would not charge.  I created and RMA with ASUS and sent it in for repairs after paying another $15 for shipping out of my own pocket.  2 weeks later the exact same tablet came back.  For about 1 month, it worked well.  But suddenly, the same problem occurred.  The tablet would no longer turn on.  So now, my options are to send it back to ASUS for repairs and dish out another $15 out of my pocket, for shipping, or just junk it and get another brand.  Now, for the second tablet.  4 days ago, the same problem just happen.

Reviews.Title: Update: I returned it
Reviews.Author: B. Shulman "Animal Lover"
Reviews.Content: UPDATE:After a month of use, this product died. It just wouldn't power up anymore. I looked back over the reviews and noticed that more than one person had the similar problem, not only here on Amazon but other sites as well. In my original review I mentioned glitches, and I should have seen the big one coming. I returned this for a Samsung tablet. How could so many people experience the same problem? If you like the product, I hope it doesn't die on you as it has done for so  many others.I am just happy that I was within my store warranty period and was able to bring it back. What follows is my original review, what I thought of the product when it was just out of the box and actually working:********What I really wanted was an iPad, but I could not justify the price as I have an iPhone and a laptop that I use a lot. I just wanted a tablet to read magazines on, and so I settled for this $150 (Cdn) tablet that I saw in a gaming shop. I'm not an Android fan at all (I went through four Android phones before finally getting an iPhone), and I'm still not an Android fan, but this tablet is worth the price and let me tell you why.It's great for reading magazines. And that's what I wanted to do on it.  Also, if you want to watch any videos, they are crisp and clear. Gorgeous visuals.So, I got what I paid for and I'm satisfied.Now here's what you need to know about Android: the battery life is terrible. Do yourself a favour and charge the device every day, or else one day you will try to turn it on and it will have gone black, meaning you have to recharge it for many hours before it clicks into gear and you can use it.Don't expect great email service. Even though the tablet connects beautifully to wi-fi, my email accounts were not syncing, so I ended up deleting them from the tablet. So there's a glitch you may want to consider.However, while I wait for the opportune time to buy a full-size iPad, this little tablet is just fine for the purposes for which I bought it, and the price simply cannot be beat, so thank you Asus for putting tablets within reach of all who want one.

Reviews.Title: Best tablet for the price
Reviews.Author: S. Jones "Staticxr"
Reviews.Content: First of all let me make it clear,  when I was in the market for a new tablet my original intention was to purchase an ipad 4 16g. Why? Idk maybe I got sacked into brands and image and marketing. But then I began to research tablets and this happened to be on sale for $120 and I was like whatever I'll buy it. I'm impatient. The body is not pancake flat or thin,  but it's nice because I'm not so scared I'll crush it while it's in my purse.  The screen does collect fingerprints fairly fast,  but For the price I'm am happily satisfied. The camera isn't the greatest,  you can forget about postcard worthy shots from the front camera all together. This little guy does exactly what I need and gets the job done just as well as a $300 ipad 2(that's the only one I've had to compare it to) in fact I would say it out performs the ipad 2 in some areas.  There have been times the ipad 2 just stopped responding all together. This cheapie has room for a micro SD card for expansion and responds every time.  I'm impressed. I basically got this to watch Netflix in bed while I travel for the holidays.  I'm able to watch and stream  seamlessly  from hulu, Netflix, hbogo, YouTube and Spotify.  I think it's got a 1.2ghz.  Either way I'm happy with the device.  If you're looking for something cheap and efficient this is definitely the one.

Reviews.Title: IT'S A LITTLE STAR!!!
Reviews.Author: Mark R. Pritchard
Reviews.Content: The ASUS MeMOPad HD 7-Inch 16 GB Tablet,  is an absolute little Star!!  It is just so easy to use! and does everything you could wish from a Mighty machine!!!!  Very clever and user friendly, it gives exceptional clarity on a great little screen!!! I can safely say I am very, very impressed! and clearly happy to have purchased such a little gem!!!

Reviews.Title: ASUS Memo Pad HD 7-Inch 16 GB Tablet (Green) is a great tablet for under $200 dollars
Reviews.Author: Christopher J. Cowen
Reviews.Content: ASUS Memo Pad HD 7-Inch 16 GB Green Tablet is a great tablet for the money.  This tablet has a beautiful display (7 inches) and displays images at 1280 x 800 pixels (800p).  The Tablet has 170-degree wide viewing angles.  Text looks sharper, colors are more vivid, and games stand out.  MeMO Pa HD 7 has a 5 MP(MegaPixel) autofocus rear camera with 100 picture continuous burst shooting and 1080P video recording.  This Tablet also has a 1.2 MP front camera.  Two of the programs that I liked that comes with this tablet are MyPainter and ASUS Studio. MyPainter allows you to demonstrate your artistic skills, while ASUS Studio lets you Manage your photos.I have listed some more specifications that I considered important for this tablet. They are as follows:* Operating System - Android 4.1 Jelly Bean* Display - 7-Inch Display* Processor - Quad Core 1.2 GHz* Memory - 16 GB Flash Memory, 1 GB RAM Memory* Number of USB 2.0 Ports - 1* Battery life 10-hour* Weight - 10.7 ounces* Item Dimensions - 7.7 x 4.7 x 0.4 inches* Wi-Fi (802.11 b/g/n)Thank you for reading my review, if you have any questions feel free to email me, I would be happy to help you with any questions you have.

Reviews.Title: product quality need to improve
Reviews.Author: Wahaha H
Reviews.Content: I purchased the tablet. It powered off and wouldn't power back on after 10 days. I requested an refund. it appears that this is a defective item. I would not recommend purchasing this tablet any time in the near future.

Reviews.Title: Excellent screen, other bits very good to excellent
Reviews.Author: pen name
Reviews.Content: As far as the hardware goes, my first impression with the MeMOPad HD 7 is very good to excellent.I really like the screen. I find it just superb, and far better than the screen that I am using to write this review. The excellent screen is what pushed me to give 5 stars rather than 4.As to other hardware on the unit, the GPS works better than a TomTom unit I had.The MeMOPAD HD 7 also seems to have plenty enough processor and memory; I haven't noticed any screen/app lag at all.With respect to storage, 16 gigabytes is a generous amount of storage space and having the ability to add more via microsd is a real win for this device.I have tried Miracast on the unit, and it seems to work fine for mirroring essentially static screens. I have not tried to stream video via Miracast yet.The speakers seem to be adequate, which is enough for me given the device has such a small footprint.As to Bluetooth, using a Perixx PERIBOARD-805L keyboard via Bluetooth seems to work well enough.The WiFi seems to work fine.As to software, well, it seems to be more of a mixed bag. I have seen a few crashes from the user interface; also, some of the system software doesn't seem to notice touch as well as I would like (I think the issue is the software in question since with other software the touch seems to work perfectly.)Software I am willing to give at least a temporary pass since both system software and apps can be updated and I am willing to give Asus time to get new releases out.Overall, I am very happy with the device. As a value proposition, it's hard to beat.

Reviews.Title: Gobal Poitioning item built in,  no other have this and the other feature for this price
Reviews.Author: JohnDoes "Sam"
Reviews.Content: GPS built in, no expensive cell contract. Torque for engine management.  Perfect for car enthusiasts.  Finding a mount for  car can be a problem but they are out there,  I went with the cd holder.

Reviews.Title: ASUS MeMOPad HD excellent choice for budget tablet!
Reviews.Author: troychicali
Reviews.Content: I had been looking for a tablet that would fit my budget (ie. what my wife would let me spend without raising eyebrows). You can't go wrong for what you get. Add to this 2nd day shipping with Amazon Prime and you can't go wrong. The display is bright and pictures and movies are sharp and highly detailed. Battery lasts all day of me constant checking emails, messages, news articles, Youtube, etc. Sure I could spend and extra $200.00 to $300.00 for top of the line, but why spend so much? Highly recommend this for anyone looking for a budget friendly tablet.

Reviews.Title: The cheapest well build tablet you can buy, without selling off an arm and a leg. Think this as Nexus 7's little brother
Reviews.Author: X. Chen
Reviews.Content: Took it out, turn it on, it works.5 mins after, asked me to update 4.2.2.Even rooting was super easy.Like other stated, microSD cards were plug and play.Cancelled my 1st order to jump on to the amazon price matching deal. And was able to get the tablet, case and screen protector for under $160 after tax. Sad I have to pay tax for amazon now. But still the best price you can possibly to get anywhere, and thanks to Prime, amazon send to my house in 1 day.For regular website/video watching, this tablet was super. Felt smaller than my old kindle 3g and also about the same size in width just slightly longer. Can't seem to be able to upload picture for this item.Pro:The screen was sharpThe speed was smoothAccepted my Micro SD card without problems.Price was cheapthe build quality very good.Con:The only problem I found was the cable that came with the tablet, it connector was hard to pull on/off the charger and the tablet. Weird.Other:I've been searching for a tablet that fits my requirement for a while. Browsed through Chinese website hoping I can score something cheap. This by far the best deal you can get anywhere. Quad core, 16GB and HD.This is my first Android tablet, but I have owned 2 Samsung smartphones, 4 Android media devices. So app wise I already have a lot purchased in Google play store. Also had three iPhones and three iPads. Since Apple and Google stuff are not interchangeable. So you have to pay separate for the same App if you have both platform devices. And the Apps doesn't function the same.

Reviews.Title: Performs well and meets my expectations
Reviews.Author: Howard
Reviews.Content: Overall, I'm very happy with this tablet, and it functions perfectly. I've had no performance issues with it at all. I simply wanted a 7" tablet with which I could email, surf the web, use Skype (which I have yet to try), and read books - and do them all well. After reading many reviews of how tablets with non-HD screens might be unsatisfactory, I waited for the Nexus 7 HD to come out. Just before it was released, this ASUS was announced, and that it would cost $80 less. Studying its features I found it would do everything I needed, whereas the Nexus would do more, but features I don't need. The $149 price for this was therefore much more palatable than $229 for the Nexus. (Despite that, I almost sprung for the iPad Mini, but it is too large and is in need of an update.) My only complaint is the lack of a comprehensive manual. It comes with a very small, several page printed one, but it's just to get you started turning it on. I had to do a search for a "real" one, and found one on the ASUS site. Though it is 106 pages, it is still not comprehensive in the way the one for my iPhone 5 is. Maybe because Android is so customizable it is impossible to devise such a manual. Oh well. They say learning a new computer program and all its quirks can help prevent Alzheimer's.  ;-)

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Dunkyj24
Reviews.Content: This is my first tablet.  I did a lot of research 2 weeks before I bought this.  I finally found the best valued tablet with every feature you could imagine, minus 3G/4G.  I am amazed at how fast it is, and how crisp the display is.  My battery is lasting more than 11 hours while playing small games.  I really like this tablet.

Reviews.Title: Love It
Reviews.Author: Adams
Reviews.Content: I love my tablet and it is the right size and the screen is very responsive and all the apps work really good. The camera is really clean. The only thing i don't like is where the power button is located it's a little uncomfortable especially with the case on.

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet!
Reviews.Author: jwow
Reviews.Content: I ordered this tablet and it showed up 3 days later.  It has been a snap to use and you does more than I expected.  I had an Ipad 2 that was going bad but was trying to stick to a budget.  This tablet Has a great display and runs fast.  Web browsing for the most part is very fast but there are a few websites I like such as IGN that can take a few more seconds to populate before than normal.  I have played some games on this tablet now as well and it performs as well.  Overall I am very happy with my purchase.

Reviews.Title: Mixed feelings on Memo Pad HD7
Reviews.Author: D. E. Reedy
Reviews.Content: I've had this tablet for about two weeks now, and I'm still torn about what I think about it. I love the fact that it cost me $150. That was great. It is also FAR superior to my 1st generation Kindle Fire that I have now passed down to my 3 year-old. All in all I'm happy that after less than two years I've gotten many more features and better performance out of a tablet that cost me 25% less than my previous one did. However . . .I don't feel like this has the build quality it should. I haven't had a lot of experience with Android devices outside of my Kindle, so I can't quite say that it's a lot buggier than other devices out there, but it is certainly buggier than I expected. Here are a few examples:1) One reason I bought this over the new Nexus 7 was because of the SD card slot. I put a 32GB card in, because I plan on using the camera a lot for both photos and videos. The problem I am having is that every time the device goes to sleep it has to re-detect the card in the slot and it doesn't always do it. At least 5% of the time it doesn't notice the card is there, so when you go to take photos the device yells at you because it doesn't have anywhere to store the photos. The only way to fix it is to pop the card out and reinsert it. The last time I tried that the card "popped" 2-3 feet into the air. Needless to say the photo op was gone.2) Probably four times in the past couple of weeks the device has refused to wake from sleep. At first I was worried that something had shorted and I was going to have to send the device back. The device seemed completely dead. Then I tried simply holding the power button and it did, eventually, reboot.3) The last straw before writing this review came because I have started using bluetooth headphones with the device. They've been working fine, until just now. I tried reconnecting headphones and it didn't work. So I turned off the bluetooth connection and tried to turn it back on. Nothing I could do would let me turn the bluetooth setting back on. It was as if it wasn't detecting the blutooth module on the device. Eventually I restarted the device and it is working fine again.4) Finally, and I don't know if this is a Google issue or an ASUS issue, but there are a number of apps in the Play store that state that they are incompatible with the device, though I can't think of any reason why that should be. A few examples include the new Microsoft Office 365 for Android app, the Starbucks app, and the mobile banking app for Citibank. They all say that they should work on Android 4.0 and later. I would say it has only been about 5% of them, but enough to be annoying.(UPDATE: I'll agree that #4 is probably a developer issue, not an ASUS issue. I don't know if this is the problem, but all of the apps I've found that are listed as incompatible have permissions settings that require access to dial the device's phone. I wonder if the Play Store assumes that a phone is necessary for the app to function.)In addition to these issues I have to agree that the build quality isn't spectacular. What I seem to notice most is that the quality of the glass doesn't seem to match the quality of the Gorilla Glass that Amazon used on their Kindles. It doesn't seem as stiff and it seems to attract and hold oil worse than the Kindle did.I feel somewhat guilty giving the device a 3 star review, but I can't quite bring myself to give it 4 stars. I'll hold onto it rather than return it because I am a fault tolerant person. If you are as well, then this might be a good deal for you. The price is certainly excellent. But if you are not fault tolerant, and especially if you don't think you will need extra storage, I'd probably recommend trying to find something more stable.

Reviews.Title: CUSTOM ROM AVAILABLE!!!!  Great Tablet
Reviews.Author: j21blackjack
Reviews.Content: I bought two of these tablets for my kids for Christmas, before the price drop unfortunately.  They are great tablets even at $149, but now that they dropped to $129 it's a no brainer!.  Found out yesterday that a custom ROM has been released for this tablet now too, it really can't get any better than this.  For anyone who doesn't know what custom ROMs are, they completely unlock the potential of the tablet and removes all the junk apps that no one wants anyway.  The performance increase is pretty ridiculous.  Check out the Custom Rom by searching for "memopad hd" on the XDA developers website.Also, the description still says Android 4.1, but it's really 4.2.2!  It will automatically detect an update, then another one after that to get to 4.2.2  And if you plan to root it, it doesn't matter what you have on it because it erases the whole tablet to start with.

Reviews.Title: This versus 2013 Nexus 7? Memopad HD hands down.
Reviews.Author: rob
Reviews.Content: My review title may seem kind of silly, given that Asus actually makes both the new Nexus 7 and the Memopad HD, competing with each other in the same market segment. There's also no disputing that the Nexus 7 is better equipped in terms of hardware.The "dealbreaker" for me is not in terms of price, although it's pretty hard for the average Joe to ignore that 35% premium for the 16GB N7 over the 16GB Memopad HD. No, it's this simple: the Memopad has a microSD slot. The Nexus 7, by design (and Google's insistence), does not.Listen, Google, if I wanted to pay more for willfully-less usability, I'd be an Apple person. Go on all you want about The Cloud. You know as well as I do that transferring several gigs of data to a mobile device is a couple minutes of my time using cheap external flash memory vs. a few hours minimum via the ballyhooed cloud. And there's stuff I don't necessarily *want* going through someone else's servers. The "OTG option" doesn't matter when you don't include the relevant cables in the box, and I don't want a USB dongle getting in my way on a portable device. So: no microSD slot, no purchase. It's that simple. I won't be buying any Nexus-line product until Google stops pretending this isn't a necessary feature and/or trying to trump up their margins Apple-style by selling two or three different models of non-expandable hardware.In other areas: is the N7's higher-res screen better than the Memopad's? Yeah, sure, it's very nice. The Memopad HD's 1280 7" screen still looks fantastic. Yes, you can tell a slight difference comparing side by side. But bring the Memopad home and you won't care any more.The N7 is a faster piece of hardware on paper, too. But the Memopad HD is very snappy and responsive, probably the fastest-feeling Android device I've personally had to date. I thought my Galaxy S3 was pretty impressive, but the Memopad bests it at least in terms of "immediate response" feel.The size / feel of the Memopad HD in your hands is absolutely perfect, and the 7" screen is surprisingly usable even with the large-format PDF books and articles I read a lot on my tablet. I was worried I'd have to keep my 10" TF101 for reading those; no more. (This all said, I don't mind or have a problem making out somewhat-small-but-sharp type.) Battery life on the Memopad is really great so far, and I have seen some pro press that suggests its battery may actually best the new N7's.Headphone jack and USB / charge port are on the same side, and Asus has wisely placed the power and volume rocker keys right together on the adjacent facet. This is the way it should be for usability's sake, and you'd be surprised how very, very many tablets (including Asus' past designs) get this wrong.I do not personally feel the device "feels cheap" at all, but the first unit I got *did* have a sort of disturbing creakiness to it in handling, the kind that I normally associate with laptops *after* I've beaten them to death in a couple years of use (just before you start seeing stress fractures). I brought it back, and the second unit I got did not exhibit this problem out of box. I would recommend slapping a case on this soon as you can, but I'd recommend that for pretty much *any* tablet. At least, unlike the iPad, you don't need to worry about the backside aluminum scratching in the first few hours of responsible ownership.The one main complaint I have about the Asus, and I don't know yet if it's even a real complaint, is that the manual makes a big deal of not leaving it perma-connected to the charger and only using their charger. The charging circuit *should* be smart enough to let me leave the thing plugged in for a week at a time without any trouble if I want. Again, this may just be some kind of weirdly-motivated instructional hyperbole on Asus' part and/or may be something you can safely ignore. I don't know yet, but personally I'll wait for other Memopad users to "do what comes (more) naturally" to find out.The Memopad HD is pretty much *the* 7" tablet sweet spot for value and performance as of this writing. It is definitely the snappy, stable, eminently usable, well-sub-$200 7" Android tablet I've been waiting for literally for years (and frankly expected much earlier).One last note: I was surprised to find that, unlike my last few Android devices, Flash wasn't working out of box. It turns out this is an Adobe-giving-up-on-mobile issue, not an Asus-build issue. Not the best news in the world, since so many of the sites I routinely visit are *still* addicted to Flash. But there do seem to be workarounds out there... for now.

Reviews.Title: Great when it holds a charge- I curse Asus's name each time I have to crack the case to get it to charge
Reviews.Author: Jason Powell
Reviews.Content: I've owned 3 tablets in my lifetime.  I only cared for one of them since it did what it was supposed to and seemed to have a ridiculously long battery life.  I sold it since it was first gen and have regretted it since getting this pos.  Typical usage for the wife and I is the occasional lookup of actors while watching tv and a bit of movie watching... but never longer than an hour.  That said I can get about 3-4 days of use before it needs charged.  That's not my gripe.My gripe is that if you aren't careful and it goes beyond a certain charge (Always when not in use it seems) than you've reached some point of no return where it will not take a charge.  After searching the web on how others deal with this very common problem I found the best action was to crack the plastic case off the back..which you can do with your fingernails...and unplug the battery connector for about 5 seconds.  Then plug it back in, snap the case back on and it will then accept a charge.I have a hard time believing Asus did not know about this problem.  And if they didn't they must have some of the worst quality of service/testing folks out there.I do not recommend this device.  I can't speak for other asus devices, just this one.  Thanks for reading.  I think this is the first review I've posted since being using amazon...wanted to steer other purchasers clear of these headaches.

Reviews.Title: DON'T BUY! THIS WILL EVENTUALLY HAPPEN TO YOU TOO.
Reviews.Author: Darren
Reviews.Content: Just like you, I read the negative reviews for this product. I decided to give it a chance anyway because I really wanted it and didn't think I'd have any problems.And I didn't have any problems... for the first two months. Eventually the device would do this thing where it would go completely dead and not turn on, even when the battery is charged. No matter how many times I pressed the power button or plugged it into the charger, it DOES NOT turn on/wake up/show charging status/nothing! The only way to fix this was to leave it on the charger and to come back to it in a couple hours. This was very annoying because it could happen at anytime, even when it's charged or on the charger. This seems to be the case with other reviewers also, but I didn't think it would happen to mine.  -___-If that wasn't bad enough, about a week later the screen became unresponsive in TWO places. I could barely use the device because my touches wouldn't register in some spots. As days went by, the unresponsiveness of the screen began to spread to more and more spots. Now I can barely click on anything! I'M DONE! I'm selling it for parts because it's completely unusable. STAY AWAY.

Reviews.Title: Junk
Reviews.Author: Jacob R. Kozlowski
Reviews.Content: These devices are riddled with bugs.  I purchases three and they've all malfunctioned and/or failed within a month.  I've requested a refund on all three.  Spend a little more and get a better tablet. These are not worth buying.

Reviews.Title: Asus Substandard product
Reviews.Author: tekvoodoo
Reviews.Content: Right after 2 months the battery stopped charging. Contacted ASUS. Sending  back to their repair house. Sad, ASUS products started giving such kinda problem. This is my last purchase from ASUS. I will look for another brand next time. Was a profound user of ASUS motherboard. Changed to MSI and Gigabytes now. Looks like ASUS is sliding from the top hill. Amazon is always great, shipped right on time.

Reviews.Title: This product is defective and a waste of money
Reviews.Author: Timothy A. Johnson
Reviews.Content: This product is defective and a waste of money.  I purchased two of these tablets; one for each of my kids for Christmas and the touch screen for both of them stopped responding after less than two months.  I sent one in to be repaired and the screen stopped working again a little over a month after the replacement was recieved.  Also know once the tablet is out of the Amazon return period you have to pay return shipping to ASUS if you send it back under the manufacturers warrenty.  A table should work for more than two months.  DO NOT BUT THIS PRODUCT IT IS DEFECTIVE!

Reviews.Title: Poor Quality. Multiple Problems.  ASUS Won't Stand Behind Product BEWARE.
Reviews.Author: S. Meakim
Reviews.Content: I ordered this for my daughter for Christmas and put it in the bobj rugged case.  It was never dropped but had problems from the very start.  It was sent to ASUS twice to be fixed.  When I got it back on the second time it went to install and update and just looped.  ASUS said I would have to send it back again.  I will never buy another tablet from them again.  The first time it died and would not recharge.  The second time was because the MicroSD card would continually mount and unmount and the tablet wouldn't recharge.  This time after the OTA it would not boot.  I could not shut it off.  I called square trade and they took care of it for me.  FYI also they try to get you to pay for shipping to them each time even under warranty.  Complain and they will cover it.  They even tried to get me to pay for shipping the second time I got it back. #ASUSSUCKS.  Please spend a little more and get a quality product

Reviews.Title: This died within 2 weeks of receiving it -- TWICE
Reviews.Author: Michael Caroff
Reviews.Content: I bought it originally last year (2013). Within a week, it just "died." Wouldn't turn on no re-charging worked, etc. So I sent into Amazon for an exchange. They sent a replacement, and that one died with 2 weeks.By the way, I didn't abuse either one. Never even took it out of my office, didn't drop it, and fact didn't even use it that much. Unfortunately, this one has now passed the "return period." Which means I paid $150 for a piece of black plastic.I would DEFINITELY recommend against purchasing this.

Reviews.Title: Was great for 5 months
Reviews.Author: A. Marsh "golf nut"
Reviews.Content: I loved this little tablet.  Smooth, fast, easy to use and navigate.  After 5 months, it just crapped out.  Nothing goes on, won't charge using any outlet, cable, or usb charger.  Dead.  And I'm very disappointed.  Buyer beware.

Reviews.Title: Quit working in less than 3 months.
Reviews.Author: faith
Reviews.Content: bought the tablet for my son for Christmas, already died, and it's only March.  It says I can no longer return it, really bummed out!

Reviews.Title: for my 5 year old girl
Reviews.Author: RoodyPoo
Reviews.Content: My daughter loves to play with our phones and tablets so we got her one to play with herself. This thing looks very well made. It is definitely not one of the cheapo tablets that quit working in a couple weeks or months. It may be as sturdy as our Samsung Galaxy tablet.  The screen is just as responsive too. Look, if my 5 year old is not having a problem with the screen, there's no way you are going to. I have used it and it is really an amazing tablet for the price. I would recommend several times over.

Reviews.Title: I'm just gunna call it out as junk
Reviews.Author: B. King
Reviews.Content: This was all fun, except The screen went unresponsive after less than 30 days.  Amazon replaced it, then the replacement went bad within 30 days. They are doing what they can, but, I should not have to mess with this kind of crap

Reviews.Title: worked for 2 months then dead!!!
Reviews.Author: Adam G.
Reviews.Content: received it 12/30.13 and it died 3/01/14. Up until it's death I loved it. This was my first tablet and while it worked it was great. It was a speedy little guy and the sound it put out was fantastic. The display was crisp and clear and it never had any problems streaming youtube or netflix. Well till death do us part and all that. Just started a warranty claim with Asus will see how that goes. I have been using Asus PC components for a decade with no problems so to say I am let down is a bit of an understatement. Sorry little bugger you would have been a 10 star review if there were such a thing but you actually have to keep alive to receive such a review and can not receive it when you are dead.

Reviews.Title: Power Issues and now dead
Reviews.Author: Jason L
Reviews.Content: I have two of these tablets and the more recent purchase is now dead five weeks later.  Both have issues of not turning on easy at seemingly random times.  Even with a charged battery there are times when I have had to plug the tablet into my laptop then hold the power button for a few minutes at a time to get it to turn on. The tablet now has not been functional for a few days and is basically a paperweight now.Update March 2014: The other tablet now has a loose micro USB port and is darn near impossible to charge.  That is a definite 0 for 2 on these now.

Reviews.Title: Tablet Died. AFTER the 30 day return window...
Reviews.Author: Aaron
Reviews.Content: Of course, this was a Christmas gift I bought for my daughter... and it waited until after the 30 day return window to stop working.  It will not turn on.  Amazon has washed their hands of it.  It's very difficult to get in touch with the Asus people about this.Not happy.

Reviews.Title: Defective micro SD card reader
Reviews.Author: Bob
Reviews.Content: Defective out of box. Would not recognize external sd card. This is a recognized problem with this unit. Went over 30 day return period with Amazon, now stuck in RMA situation with ASUS. If you want to add external memory to this tablet, BEWARE!

Reviews.Title: sent in to repairs twice already.
Reviews.Author: Ramisan
Reviews.Content: parts of the touch screen fail. battery died, and had to have it replaced.  not what i expected from ASUS.

Reviews.Title: Horrible. Two of these broke on me in two months. Please avoid!
Reviews.Author: Jim
Reviews.Content: Words cannot convey my disappointment. I've always had a loyalty towards the Asus brand. Near-Nexus 7 specs for almost half the price was too good to be true... And you know what the say about that. First one broke in two weeks, the second one in a little over a month. Now that I'm past the return window, I had to eat a restocking fee. Same problem both times, unit becomes completely bricked out of nowhere. With light to moderate use, mind you. PLEASE don't buy this. We have to get Asus back on the right track by not accepting incompetence!

Reviews.Title: Ain't gonna last long
Reviews.Author: Mon B. Gurung
Reviews.Content: Stopped working right after 2 or 3 months of using, I had to throw it in trash...Waste of money

Reviews.Title: Stopped working after 1 1/2 months!
Reviews.Author: Stacy Springer
Reviews.Content: I gave it to my 25 year old daughter for Christmas.  She used it one day and later that day it stopped working.  It will not turn on and has not been dropped or damaged.  I have found other reviews that say the exact same thing!  Unfortunately I did not buy the additional warranty.  Do not buy this model of tablet, do your own search on "ASUS MemoPad  HD 7 Tablet will not turn on".  Tried hard reset and still not working.  Very disappointed!

Reviews.Title: Quit working after less than 4 months
Reviews.Author: Austin A.
Reviews.Content: At first it seemed like a good tablet for the money, it was not as fast as I had hoped but it did the job. Then it just stopped working, will not turn on at all!

Reviews.Title: Awesome for the price
Reviews.Author: Sean
Reviews.Content: I bought this tablet for my girlfriend for her birthday (in pink, of course) and she loves it. She was previously using my Nexus 7 1st gen. Needless to say the tablets are so similar in size and construction, it was a flawless transition.The build quality of the Asus isn't up to par with the nexus 7 2012, simply because of the plastic backing that gets scratched very easily. With that said, comparing the screen quality of this tablet to that of the nexus is like night and day. Surprisingly the Asus just appears a lot more vibrant and sharper. Maybe its just my nexus, but I think the responsiveness is much better as well.This tablet isn't the fastest thing out there, as you would probably expect. But with one gig of memory and a 1.2ghz dual core processor it isn't too bad. It scores somewhere in the region of 13k on antutu, so youre looking at a galaxy S3 level of performance. Some apps to happen to slow it to a complete crawl sometimes however.Since the tablet is built on the mediatek architecture you're not going to get a lot of custom ROM support for it. I did however manage to find one that gives you some kit Kat goodies and some much needed stability improvements.We did experience the problem a lot of reviewers complained about: the tablet drains the battery and then will not turn back on. While I don't think you should have to go through this kind of thing with any product, this kind of thing happens, I guess. I contacted asus and opened up an RMA because it happened only 40 days after purchase, so amazon wouldn't let me send it back. But then I decided I'd try to fix it on my own.I popped the back cover off, removed the battery connector from the main board and shorted the terminals, kind of like a "clear CMOS" procedure on computers. Needless to say, I plugged it back in and connected the charger, and everything was good to go again! The problem hasn't happened since, and we've had it for about 3 months now.Overall if you're on a tight budget I would recommend this tablet without hesitation. The price is awesome, the screen is really good, the front and rear cameras are surprisingly better than my iPad mini retina's own, and its great value for the money. If you can manage to throw on about $80 more however, I would recommend the nexus 2013.

Reviews.Title: This tablet does support 64GB microSD cards with the latest Android 4.2.2 update.
Reviews.Author: Drad
Reviews.Content: For those of you who need or want a lot of extra storage, hopefully that helps. I've had this tablet for a few days and so far it's the best price/performance value on the market. I use it primarily as a media player and occasional web browser. I also have a first generation 32GB Nexus 7, but I really wanted the expandable storage. The Nexus is a bit faster and the build quality is better, but the Asus Memo Pad HD 7 is a full hundred dollars less than what I paid for the Nexus a year ago; I can accept a few compromises in this case. The Memo does everything I need and the slightly weaker CPU isn't an issue for my purposes. The screen resolution is the same 1280 x 800 as the 2012 Nexus 7, which seems to be better than most tablets in this price range. The screen's very responsive. Apps and pages load quickly with only the occasional and very minimal lag. 1080/720p HD video plays just fine with MX Player. Streaming depends on your connection. Heavy 3D gamers may want to look elsewhere. I don't game much, but I suspect most Android games will run fine on this. Sound quality is excellent (for a tablet) due to stereo speakers instead of mono. I can't comment on the camera, since I don't use it. Clean Master (Google Play, free) will keep the tablet running quickly and smoothly if it starts to slow down. There are some comments that the device feels cheap. I suppose that's true if you're coming from a tablet in a higher price range. In my opinion, the build quality is good for a tablet at this price.Overall, I feel that the Asus Memo Pad HD 7 is an excellent value for the money. It's exceeded my expectations at a very reasonable price. I hope that this review will help you make a more informed decision.

Reviews.Title: So far so good - But FLASH and AMAZON PRIME VIDEO DOES NOT WORK
Reviews.Author: PH 95762
Reviews.Content: Just got this for my son for Christmas.  He is 8.  He had another c-grade (archos) tablet last year for Christmas.  I actually got 2 different archos tablets last year for Christmas, 1 for son and 1 for daughter.  Both were broken, worthless in about 60 days.  I am hoping the quality of the ASUS is superior to Archos.  Google uses ASUS for their Nexus tablet so I assume they picked a good hardware partner.  So far this MeMO has worked great.  We've done some video chat via Google Hangout.  Camera quality seems good.  Play store is great.  Plenty of content.  Touch screen seems fairly responsive.  I do notice on some light gaming apps (Temple Run) there is some screen lag/ jitter.  I use the 'Task Manager' widget to stop/kill background apps and I installed and use Clean Master.  These seem to help.  My 2 ISSUES (Maybe only 1) are:1. Amazon Prime Video - DOES NOT WORK!!!  This stinks.2. Adobe Flash - 'NOT SUPPORTED ON THIS DEVICE' as quoted on Adobe web page when trying to download Flash.  I think this is the reason for issue #1 above (Amazon Prime I think uses Flash).Also, the old, broken, junky Archos tablets both had HDMI interface (one of the reasons I got them).  I wish ASUS had put HDMI on this model.  I am not counting this against ASUS as I knew when I bought it did not have HDMI.If you do not need flash or access to Amazon Prime videos this tablet is great.  I need BOTH.  I guess I did not see this information in other reviews.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: Christina M.
Reviews.Content: Got this for my 9yo for Christmas ,had to reboot several times within days of having it, and now the keyboard doesn't respond to log into the tablet..so it's a waste of money.

Reviews.Title: Best tablet for the money!!
Reviews.Author: Robert@LRS
Reviews.Content: Asus has been around a long time. Clearly their experience and knowledge can be seen in this MeMOPad!! It is fast! The resolution is awesome! Sound quality is good!! Runs everything I've downloaded including games!! I dare anyone to find another tablet in this price range as good as this!!!! I sm not a fsn of the "I" anything. Apples are for eating :-) And this Asus eats them!!

Reviews.Title: Really good product at affordable price
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I like this product. This is my first tab and wanted entry level and affordable tab. My primary purpose is to watch movies over youtube /Netflix and make video calls over skype. It is doing the job great. Resolution is really good for movies. Front camera is superb. For video calls this is one of the best tabs. Audio quality is also good for listening to music.It has around 9 GB of memory that can be used for storage (other is used by Operating system) and as you know you can extend memory. So I think we are good on memory.However you see your RAM used up to 75% all the time. It has some 970MB of ram and around 720 is always used.  So I believe it might not be good for gaming.  But I did not find any problem playing temple run.You can use some apps like cleaner to kill unnecessary processes and bring RAM usage to 600MB.

Reviews.Title: Very Happy
Reviews.Author: Pamala Smawley
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my daughter , after i had done a alot researching on what was a better tablet to buy and not cheaply made or fall apart in months to come. She is very happy with it. No problems what so ever.Fantastic product!

Reviews.Title: Works Well for $129.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This Android tablet (but with ASUS overlay) works well, has the usual Google Play store installed, and has performed all I have asked of it so far.  I was distressed that there was absolutely no documentation in the box, other than the usual warranty & disclaimer stuff.  The camera works very well, too.For the price I paid - $129 - this WAS a good deal.  I see they have upped the price, which is a real surprise; the price of ALL electronic gizmos goes down with time, not up.  So if you can get this for $130 or less, it's a good deal.  Otherwise, keep looking. The market keeps changing!

Reviews.Title: Affordable, decent and light weight + Floating app
Reviews.Author: J. THOMAS "JT"
Reviews.Content: Affordable, reasonably fast and light weight. Do not expect an apple ipad grade tablet for $120. It feels plastic. Build is cheap. I use it to read books on the road. It really serves the purpose. I wanted an affordable tablet at a tight budget and Asus MemoPad HD was the one. Floating app closed the deal for me. It allows one to run select applications like mail, calendar and calculator on top while another application is open and running. ie, a limited multitasking capability. I do not run many app at a time. When I tried, it chugged. It was expected of it. After a month use, overall I am happy to own this tablet.

Reviews.Title: Great for the price
Reviews.Author: Brian Glunt
Reviews.Content: Great tablet for the price.  Nice features for a tablet of this size, including nice amount of internal storage and the ability to add an additional 32 GB card.  Plays games well and loaded it up already with tons of apps.

Reviews.Title: Only one major issue
Reviews.Author: Jason Murray
Reviews.Content: I have been quite happy with this tablet for three weeks now.  it worked fine for the first few days even though the launcher crashed constantly. I upgraded the system firmware because I got a notification to so do and another issue presented itself. If I power the Device off, no matter what the battery level is, be it 10% 20% or even over 50%, when I try to power it on I am presented with a flash screen that depicts a dead battery and I am unable to power the tab on unless I jump start it by charging for a few seconds to minutes or power it on with power adapter attached. The only work around I have found is to not power my device off which is not an option I am quite happy with. Any known resolutions ???????

Reviews.Title: Unbelievable 7" tablet for the price!  Got mine on Amazon for $129 + Free shipping!!!
Reviews.Author: hesty24
Reviews.Content: I bought these for my children, but would not mind one bit owning one to use.  In fact, if I was allowed to use it for a week, and then the Nexus 7 2013, I would probably end up buying the MeMOPad.These are neat little tablets.  I already own and operate a Nexus 7 FHD (2013) 2nd generation, so this is what I am comparing it to.  I will say that this tablet holds its own next to the N7 2013, but is probably a bit better than the N7 1st generation.  This is because of the 5MP rear camera, and the fact that you can up the storage with a MicroSD card 32GB + 16GB on board memory.I do like the camera options on the MeMOPad a whole lot more than the N7 2013.  There are far more options with the MeMOPad than the N7 for all you picture takers out there.  The display is adequate and rivals that of most other non-N7 2013 tablets.  The speaker is loud and has no distortion at max volume, although one speaker at the bottom rear of the device, it is more than adequate.  I am using a Bobj Rugged case for the tablet.  I highly recommend that case (although it is way over priced at $21) for all those who are less than careful with your geek stuff.  Read my review on the Bobj case for more info.  Aside from the hardware differences on the tablet, the software differences are way different than the N7.  The N7 rocks a clean Android system that is upgradeable to 4.4 at this moment (not the best in the world with a lot of incompatible app issues right now, but functional).  The MeMOPad is upgradeable to Android version 4.2.2, and sports a vast plethora of ASUS apps (but they are all very nice).  I just wish that the N7 had them.  The lay out between the two take a little bit getting use to if you primarily use one device.  The screens and app opening and closing are very snappy.  The load time differences for some simple gaming apps is about 7-8 seconds longer (Hungry Shark Evolution).  Not that big of a deal to me.They MeMOPad does have a nice inclusive battery optimizing app, that is very simple to operate that states that it helps prolong the battery life.
